abstract.text: Learn about the current limitations of OpenUSD in Swift

inlineContent.text: OpenUSD in Swift is currently evolving and may change in the future. Here are some current limitations:
Prefer making incremental changes and recompile often to making large changes and recompiling infrequently
cannot be passed to function expecting
is ambiguous when it shouldn’t be (https://github.com/swiftlang/swift/pull/81709)
Some OpenUSD types are not imported
Write C++ code that wraps types you need to use from Swift. See
Some OpenUSD free friend functions (e.g. arithmetic for linear algebra) are not imported
Pass default arguments explicitly when calling C++ functions
Impacts Linux, because TfNotice support has to use Objective-C blocks to convert thick Swift closures to
, and Linux doesn’t really support that.
Hard to predict when it will occur, and annoying to workaround. (Making the return type void and adding an out-param usually works)
Would allow simplifying the patch slightly, because it currently
Would require simplifying the patch slightly
Would allow simplifying the patch a small amount. Requires
Would simplify code generation without needing to make a typedef for the nested type
Would simplify code generation and satisfying protocol requirements in C++
Would make organizing import-as-member easier and avoid polluting the global namespace
Write a non-friend function that calls the friend, and call the non-friend from Swift
Limits the ability to do import-as-member replacements
Without Swift-Cxx interop enabled, you get

inlineContent.code: Error: Cannot load underlying module for 'CxxStdlib'

inlineContent.text: , then import-as-member on new stubs that call the unavailable methods
in Swift. Workaround of using a C++ typedef works but is annoying

inlineContent.overridingTitle: https://github.com/swiftlang/swift/issues/62127: C++ interop: nested enum not imported

inlineContent.text: Worked around in Swift Package by automatically wrapping all public enums from Usd, by introspecting the Clang AST.
Workaround involves putting a typealias in downstream client projects. Not the worst, but not at all intuitive, especially since it only breaks for typenames.
Easy to wrap function in Swift Package
Doesn’t currently impact OpenUSD because I’m not adding free functions that return Usd types. But if I wanted to add free functions that return Usd types, this would be a blocker.

inlineContent.overridingTitle: https://github.com/swiftlang/swift/issues/83118: API notes should support annotating templated C++ tags

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: https://github.com/swiftlang/swift/issues/83118: API notes should support annotating templated C++ tags

inlineContent.text: This could enable me to use API notes to succinctly conform all specializations of
supplied by this repo, which is also more ergonomic

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: https://github.com/swiftlang/swift/issues/83114: Inherited methods from non-imported classes aren’t available on imported types

inlineContent.overridingTitle: https://github.com/swiftlang/swift/issues/83114: Inherited methods from non-imported classes aren’t available on imported types

inlineContent.text: Would be helpful for SwiftUsd in a few niche places.
Spurious warning that occurs in a few places when building the Swift Package. Seems harmless.
People might try to write this expression in OpenUSD, but I’ve provided wrappers for most of the cases something like this would occur.
Can be worked around by calling
in the Swift Package, or add an initializer on
Easy workaround in C++, but annoying to have to use everywhere.
I can improve the workaround by using
on the base class’s declaration of
to hide that method from Swift, then extend each subclass to add a Swift method named
that calls a C++ helper method that calls the base class’s definition of
Limits the ability to do import-as-member replacements
